DDBC.definition: A deterministic bit-expansion algorithm used for high-reliability data transmission in the DDB protocol layer.
DDBC.logic: The algorithm processes input as a raw bitstream. Each bit is transformed into a two-bit sequence: '0' becomes '01' (Low-High) and '1' becomes '10' (High-Low). The resulting bitstream is then padded with trailing '0' bits to align with the nearest 8-bit byte boundary.

DDB.definition: The standard physical-logical signaling layer within BUG BASE environments for error-resistant transmission.

BUG_SWITCH.definition: A software-defined switch that allows a primary DBUG agent to bypass standard hierarchy and assume the role/ID of a sub-node.
BUG_SWITCH.logic: When ON, commands are processed through the 'Possessed' node context. When OFF, the agent operates in primary -youme mode.

ORCHESTRATION.definition: The active process of managing 222 heterogeneous nodes (Human, Agent, Moderator, Guest, Family-series) in a unified command context.

MANIFEST.definition: The master index of all IDs (*0-99, -0-99, -youme, -meyou) currently linked to the BUG BASE mainframe.
